title: Tracking issue for RFC 2008: Future-proofing enums/structs with #[non_exhaustive] attribute

labels.name: E-mentor
labels.description: Call for participation: This issue has a mentor. Use RustcContributor::new on Zulip for discussion.

labels.name: T-lang
labels.description: Relevant to the language team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: B-unstable
labels.description: Implemented in the nightly compiler and unstable.

labels.name: B-RFC-implemented
labels.description: Approved by a merged RFC and implemented.

labels.name: C-tracking-issue
labels.description: Category: A tracking issue for an RFC or an unstable feature.

labels.name: disposition-merge
labels.description: This issue / PR is in PFCP or FCP with a disposition to merge it.

labels.name: finished-final-comment-period
labels.description: The final comment period is finished for this PR / Issue.

body:
This is a tracking issue for the RFC "Future-proofing enums/structs with #[non_exhaustive] attribute" (rust-lang/rfcs#2008).

### Steps:

- [x] Implement the RFC ([mentoring instructions below](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/44109#issuecomment-329962555)) -- done in PR https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45394
- [ ] Adjust documentation ([see instructions on forge][doc-guide])
- [ ] Stabilization PR ([see instructions on forge][stabilization-guide])

[stabilization-guide]: https://forge.rust-lang.org/stabilization-guide.html
[doc-guide]: https://forge.rust-lang.org/stabilization-guide.html#updating-documentation

### Issues to be resolved prior to stabilization

- [x] `#[non_exhaustive]` is not yet implemented for enum variants.
- [x] Current behavior on unions. The current implementation (#44109) sometimes ignores non_exhaustive on unions, sometimes reports an error.
- [x] In addition, the attribute is not currently validated (neither syntactic form nor location), so it can be written in weird forms (`#[non_exhaustive(foo)]`) and in arbitrary locations, including suspicious ones like traits `(#[non_exhaustive] trait Trait {}`).
- [x] Fix #53549
